newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia removes plantation wood export controls.
newsitem.headline: Australia removes plantation wood export controls.

text.p: The Australian government said it had removed export controls on unprocessed wood sourced from plantations in the Australian states of Victoria and Tasmania.
Primary Industries and Energy Minister John Anderson said removal of export controls on timber from plantations in the other four states was expected to be completed in the next couple of months.

Anderson said the export approval requirement had been lifted after independent scientific assessment of the two states' codes of plantation practice by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO).
Codes applying to plantations in Victoria and Tasmania adequately protected environmental heritage values, he said.
Regulations allowing the minister to remove export controls over plantation wood on a state-by-state basis were introduced by the government last year to meet an election commitment.
The lifting of controls was also an important step toward the goal of trebling the national production base by year 2000.

"Removing the export controls eliminates a substantial impediment to investment in plantations," he said. Growers now knew they would be able to seek international markets for their timber, he said. -- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
